Discounted Internet Service Available to Some Families
Onteora families can apply for discounted internet service offered through the Spectrum Internet Assist Program (https://www.spectrum.net/support/spectrum-internet-assist/). To complete your application, you will need to include a letter from Onteora School Lunch Manager Christine Downs regarding your child’s eligibility for free or reduced price school meals. Mrs. Downs will be sending out letters by the end of this week to potentially eligible families, including those with students enrolled in Kindergarten through Grade 6—all of whom are covered under the National School Lunch Program’s Community Eligibility Provision (https://bit.ly/31LmkVk). Families with older children who receive free or reduced price school meals may also be eligible for the Spectrum discount. The offer is NOT valid for families who are current Internet subscribers.

School Meal Survey
As we start the 2020-2021 school year remotely, we would like you to know that school breakfast and lunch is available for pick up for all registered k-12 students of Onteora CSD during our full remote learning. Onteora Art teacher Jennifer Wentland discusses the challenges of distance learning—from the perspective of a teacher as well as a parent—in an essay published in “The NYSATA News,” the official digital publication of the New York State Art Teachers Association. Despite the various challenges she encountered while teaching remotely, overseeing her young daughter’s schoolwork, adjusting to her family’s changing financial situation, and trying to build a house in the midst of a pandemic, she found reason for optimism. “In the end I keep thinking about the Silver Lining in all this,” she wrote. “I know for myself, I absolutely love my job.”

Reopening Schools: A Statewide, Virtual Conversation
New York State's 37 BOCES have launched an online conversation regarding how New Yorkers feel about returning to school in the fall or whenever it is possible. It consists of a single question: "What ideas and thoughts do you have as you think about a return to in-person schooling?"
A virtual conversation tool called Thoughtexchange is being used to crowdsource ideas. To participate in the exchange, visit: https://my.thoughtexchange.com/333518046.
After participants share a thought, they are encouraged to rate at least 30 of the thoughts submitted by other participants. This way, the thoughts that resonate with the most participants rise to the top.
“Understanding the thoughts and concerns of our stakeholders regarding reopening our school buildings is critical,” said Dr. Charles V. Khoury, district superintendent of Ulster BOCES. "The decisions before us are unprecedented, and we want to ensure our parents and community have a voice in this important conversation."

Important Info about Health Insurance:
With the recent closures of businesses across the State, many New Yorkers are at risk of losing their health insurance. Many are likely to be eligible for health coverage with financial assistance through NY State of Health (The Official Health Plan Marketplace) due to their loss of coverage and income.
New Yorkers who are without health insurance should apply now through NY State of Health. If you lost employer coverage, you must apply within 60 days of losing that coverage. Because of a loss of income, New Yorkers may also be eligible for Medicaid, the Essential Plan, Child Health Plus, or subsidized Qualified Health Plan coverage.
Thousands of assistants are ready throughout the State to help consumers enroll by phone.
Visit www.nystateofhealth.ny.gov for assistance in helping to find a health care plan that works for you.
If you have additional questions, you can contact the Marketplace directly at 518-486-9102 or NYSOH@health.ny.gov.

Child Care for Health Care Professionals;
Workers in Other High-Need Fields Can Apply
Project Resilience is partnering with Family of Woodstock to identify open day care slots in Ulster County and match them with health care professionals who are in need of emergency child care.
Currently there are openings for school age child care programs operated by the YMCA in Marbletown, Ellenville, Kingston, and New Paltz. To sign up, please call the YMCA’s Cailin Rooney at 845-338-3810 ext. 110.
There are limited child care vacancies in the 0-5 year old programs. Parents needing care should contact the Child Care Resource and Referral (CCRR) offices at 845-331-7080 Monday-Friday between 8 AM and 5 PM.
People who work in other high-need fields such as grocery stores, trucking, etc. may call and ask to be added to a waitlist, which will be used once all health care workers have been served.

If you live in the Onteora Central School District and have a child turning four by December 1, 2020, you’re invited to apply online for the District’s Universal Pre-Kindergarten (UPK) program for the 2020-2021 school year. UPK online registration forms must be completed by May 8, 2020.
To access the online UPK application, go to the District website or click on the following link: https://www.onteora.k12.ny.us/departments/pupil-services/universal-pre-kindergarten-program.
When your child is registered, their name will be added to a list from which the UPK students will be chosen. Onteora’s full-day Universal Pre-K enrollment is based on need. Students who receive Special Education supports, those eligible for free/reduced lunch, and/or those who are English Language Learners will be enrolled first. All other children will be chosen randomly by lottery for the District’s full-day or half-day programs.

Onteora Central School District added 11 new photos — in Woodstock, New York.
February 24 at 2:23 PM · Woodstock, NY ·

One hundred days of learning is something to celebrate, and Woodstock Elementary School recently did just that. Students and staff members held a school-wide celebration of this educational milestone on February 20.
In addition to special hats decorated with the number of day, there were plenty of games and activities that reinforced counting aptitude and honed math skills. Students made necklaces with 100 Fruit Loops, built structures out of 100 plastic cups, and assembled 10-scoop paper “ice cream cones” (with each scoop representing the number 10). The number 100 was also used as the inspiration for the creation of artwork depicting everything from a snowman to a witch to a car. A fun, educational, time was had by all!

Art lovers are cordially invited to the opening reception for “Senior Thesis,” a solo show featuring the photography of Onteora High School student Megan Davis.
The opening reception will take place at The Lockwood Gallery, 747 Route 28, Kingston, on Saturday, February 29, from 5 - 7 PM. The exhibition will run through March 6.
“Senior Thesis” is the culmination of Megan’s project for the High School’s Gifted and Talented Community Mentor Program. This year, Megan has been working on her photography with guidance from her mentor, local portrait photographer Juliet Lofaro.
Megan, who grew up in Shokan, specializes in both darkroom and digital photography. At Onteora High School, she developed her craft through classes in studio art, photography, digital art, drawing and design, and independent study.

The lessons will culminate in the coming weeks with boiling and evaporating the sap they collect into yummy syrup ready to top pancakes and other goodies!

If you have a child who will be enrolling in Kindergarten at Onteora next September, it’s time to register your child. The District’s online Kindergarten registration system is now open.
To register online, parents or guardians should go to www.onteora.k12.ny.us and click on “New Student Registration.” The link for online registration is at the top of this page.
Once your child is registered, you will be contacted with an appointment for Kindergarten screening. Screening will take place during the week of April 20-24.
Children who turn five on or before December 1, 2020 are eligible to enroll in Kindergarten beginning in September 2020.
If you have any questions, or if you don’t have access to a computer, you may contact Sharon Wood, Onteora’s District Registrar, by calling 845-657-6383 ext. 1023 or emailing swood@onteora.k12.ny.us.

To prepare for their presentation, the students met with representatives of the State Department of Transportation. The school’s FLL team is being sponsored by Ametek Rotron in Woodstock, which manufacturers fans for aircraft.

Shortly before Winter Break, the Middle School Student Government hosted “Sweet and Greet,” a celebration for students who are new to the school district this year. The event, which took place during fifth period lunch, gave the newcomers an opportunity to share concerns, ask questions, and exchange information with their hosts.
During the Sweet and Greet, the organizers moved the seats into a circle formation and placed cupcakes, brownies, cookies, and beverages on a side table. The new and old students talked about midterms, homework, and much more. Everyone indulged in sweet treats and had a great time!

December 17, 2019 at 5:51 PM ·

Onteora’s Universal Pre-K students and First Steps Preschool got festive this holiday season with a celebratory concert and party on December 11. Decked out in holiday colors and sporting seasonal accessories like reindeer antlers and Santa hats, the children spread cheer with assistance from Uncle Rock (a.k.a. Onteora Board member Robert Burke Warren). They spiritedly sang such holiday classics as “We Wish You a Merry Christmas” and “Jingle Bells,” and showed off their Spanish skills with a fun rendition of “Feliz Navidad.” They also performed Uncle Rock’s original tune, “Hold it in My Heart” (Thank You Song), which helped remind everyone of the true meaning of the holiday season. The students even received a little gift from Santa Claus himself! A very merry time was had by all!

The November 20 meeting of the School Security Regional Collaboration Committee attracted approximately 40 local school administers, technical specialists, school resource officers, and members of local law enforcement. Among those attending were Onteora High School Principal Lance Edelman, Director of Technology/Information Technology Manager John Reimer, and Detective Tom Sharon, who is returning to Onteora to serve as its School Resource Officer beginning on December 2.

Message from the Superintendent Regarding School Closings and Delays:
I know that school-related delays, dismissals, and closings put considerable stress on our school district’s families, but they are sometimes necessary to ensure the safety of our students.
Please understand that because our school district is so large (282 square miles), dangerous weather conditions may affect some areas more than others. Our Transportation Director communicates directly with our local highway departments and also studies various weather models for each weather situation. We also have to consider the size of our transportation program when we make these decisions. Once we begin dismissing students on an early dismissal day, for example, some of our bus passengers may not be delivered to their homes until up to three hours later, depending on road and weather conditions.
We have eight snow days built into our calendar, and we hope to not have to use them all, but sometimes Mother Nature has different ideas. Thank you for understanding that the safety of our students is always our paramount concern.

We have eight snow days built into our calendar, and we hope to not have to use them all, but sometimes Mother Nature has different ideas. Thank you for understanding that the safety of our students is always our paramount concern.
